name: Monkey Island™ 2 Special Edition: LeChuck’s Revenge™
description: Wannabe pirate Guybrush Threepwood, and the now zombie pirate LeChuck, return in what has long been considered one of the greatest LucasArts adventure games of all time.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP® or Windows Vista® Processor: Intel Pentium 4 3GHz or AMD Athlon 64 3000+ Memory: 256 MB RAM, 512 MB for Vista Hard Disk Space: 1.8GB free hard drive space Graphics: 128 MB with Shader Model 2.0 capability Sound Card: DirectX® 9.0c compliant sound card Controller Support: Xbox 360 controller

reviews.review_text: I grew up playing LucasArts adventure games and I was 6 years old when I played Monkey Island II for the first time. There was no internet to use when I got stuck, I solved every puzzle by myself. But playing it after 20 years was a bit frustrating and to be honest I had to use some hints. Thanks Monkey Island for making me use my brain again.

The Special Edition of the sequel is just as good as it was for the first one. We have the same areas but completely redrawn. Attention-to-detail is just excellent: switching between the new and the old version happens on the go with just a press of a button. Here you can clearly see how similar the new graphics are to the old one in terms of design elements.  Voice acting and sound effects are, of course, very good once more and they immediately get you hooked up! One notable difference compared to the previous episode is the more-easy-to-use action selection. Also, we have now extra features such as the concept arts that are accessible via the main menu and gradually get unlocked as we make further progress in Guybrush's journey.   Additionally, developer commentaries are available at various scenes - the creators of the original game discuss the fun they had with the making of the game and the various obstacles they had to overcome due to technological constraints. Oh, and in case you missed achievements from the first now you have a dozen of them ready to be unlocked.  This is a great game just as the first one and it only brings back fond memories of my childhood. I can only recommend this to the fans of the good old point-and-click adventure games and I do look forward to playing Day of The Tentacle which is the absolute must after the Monkey Island games!

Monkey Island 2: LeChuck's Revenge is the second game in the amazing Monkey Island series and probably my favourite point and click to this day   I've never been a huge fan of point and clicks because I prefer more fast paced gameplay but I was begged by a friend to try the Monkey Island series just once because it is his favourite franchise ever. MI2 went above and beyond anything I could have ever expected.  Monkey Island 2 is the second part in the adventures of Guybrush Threepwood who is, to put it politely, a rather rubbish pirate. After defeating LeChuck and 'rescuing' his love interest Elaine, Guybrush is back in search of a new story to tell and decides he will find the legendary Treasure of Big Whoop. But LeChuck has other plans....  Monkey Island 2 Special Edition brings you the original game with some added bonuses such as entirely remastered graphics, fantastic voice acting, new music, a much better and more intuitive interface and an added hint system (which might just be needed for those new to the franchise). There are also various bits of behind the scene commentary and art and for those of you who are like me; ACHIEVEMENTS. It's one of the few games I actually wanted to completed every single achievement as some were pretty amusing. You can choose to play in the remastered edition or the original and can switch between them at any point quickly and easily.  You'll spent your time exploring the Caribbean trying to uncover the mystery of Big Whoop. Along the way you'll meet some new faces and some old ones (used coffins popular these days) all of which have larger than life personalities, classic catchphrases and undefiable logical. You'll find yourself talking to every single person you encounter because you know they'll have something good to say. You'll be faced with challenges, puzzles, riddles and even the odd untraditional 'sword-fight' (I've heard you are a contemptible sneak). You'll experience the wonders of love (or at least try), make new friends (and many, many more enemies) and finally make your name as the greatest pirate ever (…).   LucasArts were able to create something fantastic with Monkey Island, combining great gameplay, a wonderful story, loveable characters and perfect humor to make a point and click adventure that'll keep you coming back time and time again. It never feels boring and it never gets old, no matter how many times you've heard the jokes, it just brings back that nice warm feeling.     Part of me feels that I missed out on something amazing never getting to play Monkey Island as a child but I am so glad I had a chance to experience it both in it's original glory and remastered. It's a shame LucasArts are no longer around to create games because they created some masterpieces in their life. Monkey Island is one of the best.

As in the case of the first title, the special edition remake works well and Monkey Island still has it even today. The UI is much better than in the first part's special edition, so playing feels a bit smoother and more relaxing. There's also an audio commentary by the devs, if one is interested.  The new graphics are good, but the truth is, MI2 had stunning graphics back in the day, and I actually prefer the old ones to some of the new ones this time. However, it's easy to toggle between the two and check out how the action looks in the other version. I played this game in Spanish like I did the previous one, just for fun to learn a word or two, works well like that also.  Recommended not only for fans of nostalgia, but also for new players looking for a relaxing trip. One just has to remember that you can't do anything wrong or die in the game (well, technically you can in one scene, but that doesn't count here). That's quite different to most games and might sound boring at first, but it isn't.

One of the best game I every played ! I'm very fond of point and clicks and I LOVE puzzles !!  I'm french so some of the jokes I didn't get (like the monkey wrench) or sometimes some things can be annoying like in the Phat's library the books name don't match the letter of the drawer so you have to search the english one. Even in the french version.  But mostly it's easy to sort it out ! I really loved it ! It's a must play !

Then it was back to the drawingboard, pen and paper and try to figure out what the game designers had in mind creating these obstacles. Hours of fun, braintwisting obstacles and great story.

Monkey Island 2 Special Edition is an excellent remake of the outstanding sequel. Much of the remake work is similar to the first game, though there are more improvements around for an even more refined and polished game. The continued story in the sequel holds up well to the first game, and a nicer remake overall does wonders to making the game experience be a pleasure.  Since this game is a direct sequel in terms of story, it is definitely recommended to play the original Secret of Monkey Island first. Gameplay is much the same of point and click adventure games. In Monkey Island 2 SE, there are a few more touches to smoothly play the game. Rather than interacting and having to bring up the entire list of verbs, right clicking brings up all available actions that can be used. This is very useful since some actions can’t be used on some objects, and it helps to see all available actions that can elicit a response from Guybrush. Item interaction is also easier, with the game defaulting to certain actions when using them. These two features are especially useful for scenes requiring some quick actions, which appear more often in MI2. A new hint feature appears in the form of object highlighting. It definitely helps for rooms with many objects, where all the objects in the room are shown by pressing Left Click and Right Click together. Also new is the Direct Control mode, where Guybrush can be controlled directly rather than using click actions. This is definitely useful for controller users who want to sit back on a big TV display. The old Classic mode switching ability is still present, and it also allows players to hear the new voiceovers while using the Classic mode UI. Overall, the same point and click gameplay is in MI2, though things definitely changed up for better navigation and controls to make things more comfortable to use.  The same great redone art style is employed throughout the game like in Secret of Monkey Island Special Edition. Overall, the redone artwork is better in MI2, since the first game did have some stiff and not very refined looking artwork. The backgrounds are a touch more fleshed out and look beautiful, and some of the character animations are smoother too. A select few characters use some 3D animation and move smoothly, perhaps a bit too smoothly from the originals. Still, the overall art quality bump in the sequel is great, with rich environments and distinct characters like the first game, but with even better quality.  Music plays a big role in the Monkey Island games, and this game still does it well with the remade songs. The sequel has some outstanding music work, much like the first game too. With the game’s soundtrack sounding great, it is nice to appreciate some of the subtleties of the music as well. Some of the themes are reused in certain areas and at times the current song slowly fades into another song when the room changes. They are very nice small touches that make playing the game feel great when they happen, and the recorded instrumentation is always a nice touch on the original MIDI compositions.  The story of Monkey Island 2 continues from the first game, focusing mainly on Guybrush Threepwood and LeChuck. I won’t elaborate on the story much since it does draw from the first game a lot, though I will say I noted that this game is slightly darker and more dramatic than the first game. There are the series’ classic funny moments, though there are just some actions the player has to take and some story directions the writers made that makes the tone just slightly different. It’s a solid Monkey Island game though, with great moments and a well-crafted story for those who played the first game.  The remade sequel provides a nice experience, comparably better than the first game in certain parts. Gameplay is mostly the same, though a few additions to make navigating the game smoother are welcome touches to use. The art is still great to look at, and there are some considerable improvements in quality from the previous game. The music is outstanding as ever, with some subtle transitions and arrangements being employed on the soundtrack for a great listen. Monkey Island 2 Special Edition is a remake that stands up to the original game, with well-deserved refinements that make it a blast to play through.
A great remaster of a classic. Fantastic jokes, music, characters, and clever puzzles. If you like point-n-click adventures, and you haven't played this series, what are you waiting for?
Stop looking at reviews and put this on your Wishlist. It's the best point-and-click adventure game ever made and it's been updated to look amazing. 10/10. Easily.

One of my favorite games of all time... perfectly remastered. It's crazy to think how much time I put into this at 8 or 9 years old and actually finished the game. Trying to remember how to solve all the game's plot-puzzles really hurts my brain nowadays xD   Definitely one of the best of the Lucas Arts 'SCUMM' titles, highly recommended.
Ideal sequel for nice adventure. And good remake too.
look behind you, a 3 headed monkey!

It's the classic forged in the golden era of LucasArt everybody loved, but revamped.  If you like adventure games and never played it, now it's your big chance of grabbing some sweet updated game history. The humour is soberb just like the story.

I really wanted to like this game; and I did like a lot of things about it. It's very pretty to look at and the music is nice. The characters are distinct and interesting and the dialog is endearing, funny, and delivered well. And the story's not bad...mostly.  The reason I don't recommend this game is that it's too hard. By that I mean that a substantial number of the things you have to do to advance the game are completely idiosyncratic. When I have to break down and consult a walk through for a point-and-click game my reaction to learning the solution usually falls into one of three categories:  1.) 'Well, I feel stupid for not identifying that obvious and imminently reasonable solution.' 2.) 'Oh, that was clever. I bet figuring that out on my own would have been satisfying.' 3.) 'F*** you, game. That makes no sense.'  About 1/3 through the game, my wife and I broke down and checked a walk through because we had a bazillion inventory items and a half dozen hopelessly stalled leads. The solution was soundly in the 'F*** you' category. So were the next two solutions that we had to look up shortly thereafter. At that point we threw in the towel and just sailed through the last half of the game with a walkthrough. I have no shame. We're adults and have stuff to do that doesn't involve spending six months rubbing everything on everything else in an attempt to move the plot forward. Also, the genuinely clever and funny dialog? It gets a lot less funny when it loops 100 times while you're standing on one screen for 15 min clicking on all the things with all the other things. Admittedly, once we just followed a walkthrough, the game wasn't half bad in a visual novel kind of way.  So, yeah. I guess I could recommend this game (especially for the $2.49 it is at time of writing) if you are ok with playing through with substantial help of a walkthrough or are 11 and have months to click on all the things, forever. Or if you're psychic, I guess.   Also, I thought the ending was really lame, though that's kind of a taste thing. Personally, if I had slogged my way through this without a walkthrough I would have been mad.
DO NOT PURCHASE THIS GAME. IT HAS A GAME BREAKING BUG. LUCASARTS AND STEAM HAVE DONE NOTHING TO FIX THIS ISSUE.
Too slow paced. Probably good for a younger gamer.

For those who have never played this game; buy this and Monkey Island 1 now, you won't regret it. Monkey Island 2 represents one of the high water marks of adventure games.
Monkey Island cool game old school point and click
It's really fubby and fun puzzles. It's a great point-and-click game.
Great LucasArts classic! Challenging puzzles for newcomers. Hope they re-make Full Throttle next! :D

If you have yet to play the original version, get this instead. This 1ups the previous special edition by having much better UI, Guybrush looks even greater in his best look (In my opinion, shame they made him look like MI1 Guybrush in MI3) and haivng commentary of the developers which are quite interesting and amusing. This is one adventure you can enjoy playing twice. If you use a walkthrough, the fun is over.  Except for one time where a certain part of the game is much easier when you use classic mode.

In all it's mystery, it's still just as funny now, even though it has a new soundtrack. Monkey Island ended on such a great final note, I was surprised there was a sequel, but not surprised that it was this good.  I still love Monkey Island and it's still just as confounding, humourous, and fun in this sequel. It's still a point-and-click adventure with a great (not for sale) soundtrack, quirky characters and ironic settings. Everything is there to love, even the confouding unanswered ending that begs a sequel which has yet to come, making it one of gaming's greatest mysteries. If you haven't played either of these games in the decades they've been out, they are definitely worth your time.
Guybrush threepwood. Always good times with him. Wish he didn't always forget his ID so we could get him some more Grogg.. Fun puzzles, fun dialogues.
Just like the first part, apsolute jewel and a must have for any gamer's collection. A masterpiece.

HILARIOUS! Either if you played the original or you're a 'Special Edition starter', YOU'LL LOVE THIS GAME! You'll laugh at every line and twist of the game. Cult AND Gaming Masterpiece! But I must warn, although not necessary, if you want the full experience, play the first game (The Secret of Monkey Island) first. One of my favorite games ever.

Second adventure for our wannabe hero Guybrush Threepwood, Mighty Pirate, in the search for the legendary treasure of Big Whoop. He still doesn't know that he'll cross his way and his sword with the Zombie Pirate LeChuck in search of revenge and Elaine Marley, his ex-fiancée. Fantastic sequel for The Secret of Monkey Island and last game of the Original Ron Gilbert Timeline of events for our unlucky hero. A pixelated masterpiece with a great story and a great soundtrack back in 1991, remastered in 2010 with an exceptional orchestral soundtrack and breathtaking 2.5D graphics!! Incredibly funny humor, with unforgettable protagonists, antagonists and side characters. Playable and replayable at every age with the same strong grip even after decades!! Tenouttaten
Who doesn't want to be a pirate? Guybrush Threepwood surely does. This game is a classic and I just wish more games like this would be created.
Monkey island... A great license which really deserved the HD edition. And this one is even better than the firts one. Just try it (but play the first one before to really appreciate it).
Monkey Island 2 is most certainly the best game ever made.
Classic adventure at it's best.  The only thing I wish this game had is insult dueling...  Slightly inferior than the first one, but still a lot of fun.

The same classic we all loved, but better! Fantastic new art works and music kick life back into this beauty. Updated inventory systems, hint systems, animations - it's all improved whilst keeping the Monkey Island feel. Even for those who fear change, they implimented a 'Change back to Original' key - usable at any time. Tons of extras for the die hard fans such as developer commentary and a concept art library. All that for a small price forges this into the ultimate steal of a lifetime!
I do not remember exactly how many hours I've played the game. But the 11 disks verson for the amiga was a little bit irritated

Score: 8/10  Monkey Island is a classic games from the DOS era. Curse of the Monkey Island (COMI/MI3) is one of my first games in this genre, point and click game and it really got me interested for more point and click games. This game, Monkey Island 2 is even older than me!  In this special edition, the images were hand redrawn and instead of using the verb table, you just click on items on screen directly much like in COMI except for a few puzzles. There are also object highlighting and hint system which you can ask for a hint or literally a pointer. Still, the graphics was just a draw over the old game in order to enable the 'classic version' seamless switch and it feels a bit rough in the remastered edition.  I don't know how to review the story without being bias. So just take my word and try out Monkey Island at least for its cultural root. For more beginner-friendly experience the third game, Curse of Monkey Island (not on Steam/GOG and no special edition, its cartoony graphics quite withstanding the time) is much improved.

I like to click items. I clicked on paper once, and later on I clicked on a stick. These things are now in my inventory! Usually these things have to be clicked in a certain order, which can be difficult at times - but ultimately rewarding. I don't like the revamped visuals, so I don't use them.

The definitive version of all game remakes!  If you loved The Secret Of Monkey Island Special Edition, Then this is no exception!  On the plus side if you get stuck, The game has a hint feature that tells you what to do next.
Absolutely hilarious. If you haven't played the first, I'd recommend giving it a go before playing this one: then you'll get some of the in-jokes.
As with the first Monkey Island remake, this one is a must-have for fans of point-and-click adventure games. Relive childhood memories in high definition!
A great game from my childhood

I found this game to be much better than the original monkey island game. The ending is well worth it. But the game can be long only if you feel like your running everyonewhere only to find that what you needed was where you just left. Just have patience, an open mind, and a sense of humor and you'll like this game a lot. I loved it.
The classic game with new art, music, voice acting, and a commentary track with the creators. Buy it.
This is the epitome of the zany Point-and-Click. The humor holds up, even after all this time. A wild ride, and can be completed by the puzzally-challenged with the in-game hint system. Go for it!
Very fun if you like point and click

I usually HATE Remakes. I'm sick of Hollywood regurgitating old ideas. But this... This is awesome. The classic Monkey Island games, just not all pixel'd (Not that there's anything wrong with that), and with the voice actors we've come to know and love ever since Curse of Monkey Island. Well...except for Otis. He's got a different voice, but... It's freakin' Otis. He's got like, 6 or 7 lines.
This is fun, but complicated! I remember playing Monkey Island in grade school. It's worth a try if you can get it for $12 or less.

Great remaster of one of the best adventure games ever.  New completely redrawn graphics, new voice-overs, sound effects, controls and if you wish you can listen to developers commentaries in almost every location p.s. and it costs less than 20$, so it's fine ten outta ten
A classic game that is perfectly redone, great graphics, great voice acting, a must to play for people that played the original and also to people that is new to the MI franchise.
Great story, great characters, great comedy, great puzzles, great music, great voice acting, great graphics...  It's great. My all-time favourite.
Who doesn't want to be a pirate? Guybrush Threepwood surely does. This game is a classic and I just wish more games like this would be created.

Completely stands the test of time. A hallmark of what Point and Click adventure games have to offer. Witty dialogue, interesting stories, engaging banter, three headed monkeys and vudu!  Played it for the first time at least 15 to 20 years ago. Will keep playing it for another decade.
Probably the best of the mid 90s Lucasart 2d point-n-click games, and that says a lot. the remaster is decent enough, and include the original within it anyway.

This game was really LucasArts at their finest, long enough to grip you but not so long as to be boring and a great all round click adventure game that has really stood the test of time as evidenced by this reboot with updated graphics!

Taught me the most annoying puzzle you can imagine, and you can do it in real life to anyone you meet. Now you can spread the frustration around! If you don't like frustration (you weirdo) there's an easier difficulty to just enjoy the game.  One of my all time favorite games, it just has it all.
